thread.title: U.S. Cross Country Championships Turn Into a Mud Run
thread.title_full: U.S. Cross Country Championships Turn Into a Mud Run

title: U.S. Cross Country Championships Turn Into a Mud Run
text:
U.S. Cross Country Championships Turn Into a Mud Run The race in Bend, Oregon, was a qualifier for the world team going to Uganda. By Erin Strout Monday, February 6, 2017, 1:16 pm 
During the days leading up to the USA Track & Field Cross Country Championships on Saturday, in Bend, Oregon, volunteers took shifts on the course to shovel off two feet of snow. The result was a runnable trail—what some called a “true cross-country experience”—with plenty of muddy stretches for athletes to negotiate. Six of the top finishers in the junior and senior divisions will comprise the U.S. team competing at the world cross-country championships on March 26 in Kampala, Uganda. 1/7 Michael Scott 
Aliphine Tuliamuk wins the women’s race. 
The 27-year-old who trains in Sante Fe, New Mexico, and competed for Witchita State University became a U.S. citizen last April. Tuliamuk collected her fourth U.S. title on Saturday, winning the women’s 10K in 34:25. 2/7 Michael Scott 
Leornard Korir is the men’s winner. 
Korir, 30, takes the men’s 2017 title in 30:12. He's a member of the American Distance Project, and the team swept the top four spots in the men’s race. Korir also competed in the 10,000 meters at the Rio Olympics. 3/7 Michael Scott 
Melody Fairchild takes the masters crown. 
Fairchild, 43, of Boulder, Colorado, wins the women’s masters division 6K. It was a triumphant return to her roots in cross country, as Fairchild won the Foot Locker Cross Country Championships in 1989 and 1990. 4/7 Victah Sailer 
A former champion returns. 
Chris Derrick, 26, from Portland, Oregon, places fifth and secures a spot on the world championships team. He won the U.S. cross country championships three years in a row from 2013 to 2015. 5/7 Victah Sailer 
No one avoids the slop. 
Korir, the eventual winner, and his U.S. Army teammate, Shadrack Kipchirchir, negotiate a field of deep mud. Kipchirchir placed third in 30:19. 6/7 Victah Sailer 
Snow lines the course. 
The men stick to the path cleared by snow-shoveling volunteers during the days leading up to the race. Wintry weather subsided on race day. 7/7 Victor Sailer 
Women fight for places in the top five. 
On her way to a fifth-place finish, Sarah Pagano, 25, of Boston, leads Courtney Frerichs, 24, of Portland, Oregon. Frerichs finished in fourth place by four seconds. Advertisement
